results.title: Tin miners of Malaysia
results.brief_description:
Examines Kinta Valley area in the Malaysian mountains which contains the world’s largest tin deposit. Follows a 16 year old boy and his family to show lifestyles of Malaysian miners and to increase the understanding of a country whose people are of many races and national origins.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Tin from the Malayan jungles
results.brief_description: A map shows the areas of the richest tin deposits in Malaya. Scenes of prospectors locating the deposits are followed by illustrations of the two main mining methods. Open cast by means of the hydraulic method or by power shovel and dredging using an enormous dredge. The dredging is considered the most productive and effective. The earth is processed until from 75 to 77 percent pure tin is derived. This is shipped to Singapore for refining and smelting.

results.title: Tin can craft
results.creator_credit: Boy Scouts of America. Visual Education Service
results.brief_description: Shows how camping utensils can be made from tin cans. Demonstrates the making of kettles, cups, pans etc. Stresses that clean cans must be used, with smooth edges, and that care must be taken when cutting the tin.

results.title: Timpson's country churches
results.brief_description: Join John Timpson as he traipses across the country in search of churches and the oddities, curiosities and tales they harbour. John visits over twenty churches, reflecting on them with amusement and affection and an interest in the people who maintain country churches, thus perpetuating the position of churches in village life.

results.title: Timor: island of fear, island of hope
results.creator_credit: Timor Defence Foundation and Boubaker Adjala
results.brief_description: An historical introduction to East Timor as well as a commentary on contemporary political and military conflicts. Includes film reports from four Australian journalists killed at Balibo in October 1975 and footage of Australian Labor MHR Ken Fry at the United Nations.

results.title: Times are changing
results.creator_credit: Ben Cardillo, Australian Film Commission and Mitch Matthews
results.brief_description: A contemporary Australian story which considers the effects of unemployment on family life. George loses his job after 35 years of employment and not knowing how to tell his wife and family, pretends to go to work each day. Ideal for considering the value of work and study, the importance attached to work as viewed by different generations, family relationships, traditional sex roles, technological change and communication. Lead role played by Max Cullen.

results.title: Timeless treasure
results.brief_description: Deals with the continual deterioration and destruction of man’s cultural heritage and the need for active preservation. Shows rebuilding and restoration work, and discusses the role of UNESCO’s International Study Centre for the Restoration and Preservation of Cultural Property in organising and assisting such undertakings as safe-guarding the temples threatened by the Aswan Dam in the Nubian Valley

results.title: Timeless Temiar
results.creator_credit: Malayan Film Unit and Zain Hussain
results.brief_description: Shows the life of the Aborigines of the Temiar tribe of Northern Perak, Malaya. They lead a civilised life when left in their own environment and make full use of jungle resources.
